thread.title: Back pain increases chance of early death in elderly
thread.title_full: Back pain increases chance of early death in elderly

author: Henry Bodkin
title: Back pain increases chance of early death in elderly
text:
P eople who suffer from back and neck pain in old age have a greater chance of early death, a new study has found.
Research of nearly 4,400 people over 70 revealed that those with spinal pain were 13 per cent more likely to die each year.
Back pain affects four out of five Britons at some point and costs the country £4.8billion a year in medical treatment, drugs, benefits and lost productivity.
This is a significant finding as many people think that back pain is not life-threatening Dr Matthew Fernandez, University of Sydney H owever, few studies have examined the potential reduced life expectancy associated with spinal pain in an ageing population.
The Sydney University scientists behind the new findings said they did not know whether and how back pain causes early death.
But previous research has suggested that chronic pain can wear down people’s immune systems and make them more vulnerable to disease.
“This is a significant finding as many people think that back pain is not life-threatening,” said lead author Dr Matthew Fernandez.
"These findings warrant further investigation because, while there is a clear link between back pain and mortality, we don't know yet why this is so.
“Spinal pain may be part of a pattern of poor health and poor functional ability, which increases mortality risk in the older population,"
Back pain can be caused by muscle strain Credit: Sebastian Kaulitzki E arlier this month, colleagues at Sydney University published research indicating that common over-the-counter painkillers like ibuprofen make hardly any difference to people with chronic back pain.
UK health chiefs still advise GPs consider prescribing non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in the first instance, however medical opinion is increasingly moving towards advising exercise as the best solution for persistent back pain.
"With a rapidly growing ageing population, spinal health is critical in maintaining older age independence, highlighting the importance of spinal pain in primary health care as a presenting symptom,” said Dr Fernandez.
"Back pain should be recognised as an important co-morbidity that is likely to impact people's longevity and quality of life."
The Study was published in the European Journal of Pain.
It's often caused by a simple muscle, tendon or ligament strain and for most people improves within a few weeks or months.
